moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. f4: Zuckertort chooses a different gambit -- the Vienna Gambit. In any case it will make for an exciting game: gambits usually do, unless they are declined.
moves.3... Bc5: Instead of taking the Pawn, Rice gambits his own KP in return for...
moves.4. fxe5 Bxg1 5. Rxg1: ...doubling White's KP and destroying his ability to castle K-side.
moves.5... Qh4+ 6. g3 Qxh2 7. Rg2 Qh3: Rice has equalized the material, but his Q is dangerously exposed.
moves.10. Bf4 Bg4: Rice is unafraid of the grandmaster: he intends to attack.
moves.11. Qd2 Bf3 12. Rf2 Qh5 13. Bxd6: Zuckertort clears the obstruction to his center Pawns.
moves.13... Rd8 14. e5 Nge7 15. Qf4: Doubling on the KB file, aiming at the weak spot on KB7.
moves.17... h6 18. Rdf1 Rd7 19. Bg4 Be6: Allowing Zuckertort to remove a guard on KB7.
moves.20. Bxe6 Qxe6 21. Qxf7+ Qxf7 22. Rf2xf7: Zuckertort takes advantage, swapping down. His passed KP will be a bigger advantage with every pair of pieces exchanged.
moves.22... Nxd4 23. Nd5 Ndf5: Zuckertort pounces on this mistake, augmenting his material advantage by obtaining two pieces for a Rook.
moves.24. Rf1xf5 Nxf5 25. Rxf5 Kd8 26. c4: In addition to his central passed Pawn, Zuckertort now threatens to convert his flank majority on the Q-side into a second passer.
moves.26... b6 27. Bf8 Ke8 28. e6: With this forcing move, Zuckertort induces the exchange of all the remaining pieces, setting up a winning K and P end game.
moves.28... Rxd5 29. cxd5 Rxf8 30. Rxf8+ Kxf8: Zuckertort's advanced central Pawns now prove decisive.
moves.31. d6 g5 32. g4: Rice resigns. One of Zuckertort's Pawns will inevitably become a Queen.
